title: How to Prevent Mildew Growth

steps.headline: Open windows or use fans to increase the airflow in your home.
steps.description: Airflow through your homes helps move mildew spores around so they don’t settle on any surfaces. Open some windows around your home so there’s a comfortable breeze blowing through them. If you don’t feel a breeze after opening windows, use floor or ceiling fans to help move the air around. If it’s already humid outside, avoid opening your windows since you could let some of the moisture indoors. Open windows on the opposite side of your home if possible so the air can come in one way and out the other. That way, mildew spores blow out of your home rather than circulating around it.

steps.headline: Fix any leaks as soon as you notice them.
steps.description: Mildew needs moisture in order to grow, so leaky pipes or showers can be problem areas. Look around your home for any water fixtures that have water pooling near them or that have a leak. Either try to patch the leak yourself or hire a professional to fix it for you . If an area in your home smells musty, you might have a leak or standing water nearby. Check any faucets or pipes nearby to see if there is any water coming out of them.

steps.headline: Allow light into dark, musty areas so mildew is less likely to grow.
steps.description: Closets and basements are susceptible to mold and mildew since they are dark and enclosed spaces. Leave closet doors open when you can so they can air out and get light throughout the day. If you can’t leave the door open, put a small, battery-operated light in the space and turn it on for about 20-30 minutes each day. Keep curtains and blinds open throughout the day so your home gets direct sunlight.

steps.headline: Turn on an air conditioner to keep the air cool in hot, humid weather.
steps.description: Air conditioners help lower the humidity in your home and keep your space cool so mildew can’t form. Keep your windows closed while you run the air conditioner so the cold air doesn’t escape. Run your air conditioner frequently during humid weather so mildew doesn’t have a chance to settle on the surfaces. You can either use a central air conditioner or a window unit to cool your home. Use an air conditioner as well as fans to move the cool air throughout your home so you have good airflow.

steps.headline: Use dehumidifiers in rooms that have a lot of moisture.
steps.description: Dehumidifiers take the moisture out of the air and make your room less humid. Run your dehumidifier during the day to absorb the moisture and make stop mildew spores from growing. Aim to keep your home between 30-60% humidity so it’s comfortable and mildew-free. When it’s not humid outside, turn off the dehumidifier so it doesn’t get too dry in your home. You can buy dehumidifiers from any home goods or appliance store.Tip: Some dehumidifiers have timers so you can set them to turn on and off and certain times during the day.

steps.headline: Remove any existing mildew with a general multi-purpose cleaner.
steps.description: Get a cleaner that has antifungal or antibacterial properties so it kills any harmful spores of mildew. If you already have mildew forming in your home, spray the area with your multi-purpose cleaner and wipe it with a cleaning rag or paper towel. Make sure you remove all of the mildew or else it will regrow and continue to spread.Tip: If you don’t want to use a chemical cleaner, mix white vinegar and a few drops of any scented essential oil in a spray bottle to use instead.

steps.headline: Clean high-moisture areas regularly so mildew can’t grow.
steps.description: Pay special attention to rooms like the bathroom, basement, laundry room, and kitchen since they develop mildew the easiest. Wipe down any wet surfaces using a multi-purpose cleaner with antifungal agents to prevent mildew from settling and growing. Try to clean the rooms at least once per week so they never get too dirty.

steps.headline: Soak up any spills immediately so the moisture doesn’t get trapped.
steps.description: If you spill any liquid on a carpet or piece of furniture, use paper towels or cleaning rags to pull the moisture out from it. Apply a firm amount of pressure to the spill so you can soak up as much of the liquid as you can. Keep soaking up the spill until it’s dry before applying an antibacterial cleaner to prevent mildew from forming. If you leave spills untreated, then they could develop mildew and make your repairs more expensive. If a spill got deep into the carpet, you may need to shampoo it.

steps.headline: Dry damp clothing immediately so it doesn’t form any mildew.
steps.description: Don’t let wet clothing or fabric sit around since it will start to develop mold and mildew. Instead, put them in a machine dryer or hang them on a rack to air dry completely. Make sure there’s good airflow in the area you hang items to dry or else they’ll stay damp. Wet clothes can make your home more humid if they’re air-drying, so use a dehumidifier to help remove some of the moisture.

steps.headline: Apply a mildewcide to exterior walls to protect them.
steps.description: Mildewcide is a preventative chemical that stops mildew from growing on surfaces, such as exterior walls or roofing. Get mildewcide for interior or exterior use depending on where you want to apply it and follow the directions carefully. Make sure to coat all of your walls evenly so there aren’t any gaps where mildew can grow. You can buy mildewcide from hardware and home improvement stores. Mildewcide usually lasts for 1 year before you need to reapply it. Many interior paints have mildewcide mixed in them already, but if they don’t, you can stir it in yourself.

text: Controlling the Humidity and Airflow Open windows or use fans to increase the airflow in your home.
